docs.lead_paragraph: As a preschooler, Jennifer Parilla often climbed onto her parents' bed and jumped as high as she could. ''I loved the feeling of flying,'' recalled Ms. Parilla, of Lake Forest, Calif. Then, when she was 5, she began lessons in the sport of trampolining. Now 18 and the national women's trampoline champion, Ms. Parilla has a chance to demonstrate her sport before an enormous audience. Last month, the International Olympic Committee announced that trampolining would be a competitive event at the 2000 games in Sydney, Australia.

headline.main: For 'Bouncers,' a Chance for the Gold

docs.abstract: International Olympic Committee recently announced that trampolining would be competitive event at 2000 games in Sydney, Australia; this made-in-America sport is dominated by countries like Russia, Belarus and France; Jennifer Parilla, lead American women's competitor, is ranked 15th worldwide; top American men's trampolinist, Ryan Weston, is rated 8th; photo (M)
